Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US — a land where anyone from anywhere can pick themselves up, put down roots, start anew, thrive, succeed—in other words, a land of immigrants and opportunity. And one where the taxpayers pay for everything.

The Dutch — a place that values privileged educations, subsidizes foreign workers, and pays

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, but the crowding and the overuse of jump-cuts make it feel more like a three-minute television clip than a full-length motion picture. Both sex and violence are overused to the point where these components are laughable and distracting (especially when shown in graphic slow-mo).

Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is the first of three starring the martial artist. The film was shot in the Philippines, and it shows with the difference in culture, colors, and thick jungle.
